message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: 
public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
        int n1 = 3; // number of rows
        int n2 = 3; // number of columns
        int[][] a = new int[n1][n2];
        StringTokenizer st1;

        for(int j=0; j<n1; j++){
            String s2 = br.readLine();
            st1 = new StringTokenizer(s2);
            for(int k=0; k<n2; k++){
                a[j][k] = Integer.parseInt(st1.nextToken());
            }
        }

        // Print the array to verify
        for(int i=0; i<n1; i++){
            for(int j=0; j<n2; j++){
                System.out.print(a[i][j] + " ");
            }
            System.out.println();
        }
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: The given code reads lines from the standard input, tokenizes each line using the StringTokenizer class, and then parses each token as an integer to be stored in a 2D array. The StringTokenizer.nextToken() method is used to get the next token (integer) from the current line. The number of rows and columns in the array are defined by n1 and n2 respectively. After reading and storing all the integers, the code prints out the 2D array to verify the result.
